Line 4: Line 4:  
A "moral" may refer to a particular principle, usually as informal and general summary with respect to a moral principle, as it is applied in a given human situation.
 
A "moral" may refer to a particular principle, usually as informal and general summary with respect to a moral principle, as it is applied in a given human situation.
    −
[[philosophy|philosophers]] talk more about [[ethics]] then morals (although they often use both words interchangably). Ethics is an intellectual approach to moral issues that asks questions like how one ought to behave in a specific situation (e.g. is abortion morally permissible? This area of philosophy is more appropriately called applied ethics), how can one justify a moral position (e.g. if I think I am morally justified in telling a lie to protect a friend from someone who would do them harm, how would I go about justifying my position? This area of philosophy is known as normative ethics), and finally philosophers ask meta-ethical questions which are questions about the justification of ethics/morality itself (e.g. Do the terms "good", "evil", "right", "wrong" makes sense, and how do we justify the existence of "good" or is it all relative and morallity simply a statement of one's preferences (also known as cutural reletavism).
+
[[philosophy|Philosophers]] talk more about [[ethics]] then morals (although they often use both words interchangably). Ethics is an intellectual approach to moral issues that asks questions like how one ought to behave in a specific situation (e.g. is abortion morally permissible? This area of philosophy is more appropriately called applied ethics), how can one justify a moral position (e.g. if I think I am morally justified in telling a lie to protect a friend from someone who would do them harm, how would I go about justifying my position? This area of philosophy is known as normative ethics), and finally philosophers ask meta-ethical questions which are questions about the justification of ethics/morality itself (e.g. Do the terms "good", "evil", "right", "wrong" makes sense, and how do we justify the existence of "good" or is it all relative and morallity simply a statement of one's preferences (also known as cutural reletavism).
